docs.lead_paragraph: When Tommy G. Thompson, the secretary of health and human services, spoke to the American Public Health Association on Monday, he had an audience of more than 6,000 people eager for guidance on the anthrax threat. But he left some of them disappointed. ''He arrived late, he gave his speech, and he scooted right out,'' said Carole Zimmerman, a spokeswoman for the group, the premier organization for public health professionals in the United States.

headline.main: In Anthrax Crisis, Health Secretary Finds Unsteady Going
headline.kicker: A NATION CHALLENGED: THE CABINET SECRETARY

docs.abstract: Health Sec Tommy G Thompson, despite reputation as saavy political operator, is off to rocky start in handling anthrax crisis; faces complaints about missteps, miscues and misstatements; says he has been frustrated at times in his efforts to get and disseminate data on disease; cites classification of some data and Federal Bureau of Investigation curbs on other disclosures; holds national response to problem is improving daily; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: INTERNATIONAL A3-15 Israeli Troops Advance Despite Bush's Plea Israeli troops pushed into a seventh West Bank municipality, Beit Rima, killing at least 5 Palestinians and arresting 11, including 2 who the Israelis said helped kill a cabinet minister last week. Earlier, President Bush appealed for an Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territory. A14 Britain Reciprocates in Ulster Britain said it was dismantling three military watchtowers and one base as part of a program of troop reductions, base closings and ''security normalization.'' The moves were in response to the long-awaited decision by the I.R.A. to begin laying down its arms to preserve the Northern Ireland peace process. A3

docs.lead_paragraph: For all their recent pledges of bipartisanship, Republicans and Democrats are headed for an ideological showdown over how best to revive the economy. Republicans are pushing for tax cuts for corporations. Democrats are seeking to put money in the hands of low- and middle-income people and workers who have lost jobs. Both sides have reached the point where it has become all but impossible to paper over the depth of their differences.

headline.main: Lawmakers' Votes on Economic Legislation Will Test Talk of Bipartisanship

docs.abstract: Republicans and Democrats in Congress are headed for ideological showdown over how best to revive economy; Republicans in House are pushing for $100 billion in tax cuts, $70 billion of them for corporations; Democrats in Senate unveil $70 billion stimulus plan that would include $33 billion for expanded unemployment and health-insurance benefits, $14 billion of tax rebates for low- and moderate-income people and $20 billion in of temporary tax cuts for business (M)
docs.snippet: For all their recent pledges of bipartisanship, Republicans and Democrats are headed for an ideological showdown over how best to revive the economy.    Republicans are pushing for tax cuts for corporations. Democrats are seeking to put money in the...

docs.lead_paragraph: U.S. Obtains Concession On Price of Anthrax Drug The Bush administration said that it had won a price concession from Bayer for its anthrax medicine, Cipro, after the White House threatened to buy generic alternatives instead. A spokesman for the Department of Health and Human Services said that the government had reached an agreement in principle with Bayer to buy the medicine for less than $1 a tablet. The company had planned to charge $1.83 a tablet. [Page B7.] An administration official said that the government was in talks with seven companies to build a stockpile of smallpox vaccine. [B7.]

docs.lead_paragraph: KPMG, the international accounting firm, agreed yesterday to pay $9 million to settle government accusations that it helped a group of hospitals in Florida and Kentucky defraud Medicare through the use of bogus expense claims. The government lawsuit against KPMG was an outgrowth of a multiyear investigation of the company now known as HCA-The Healthcare Company. Federal investigators have said in court records that they think HCA and its predecessor companies engaged in a corporatewide effort to cheat the government by misrepresenting certain expenses, which were then reimbursed by Medicare.

headline.main: KPMG Is Paying $9 Million To Settle Medical Fraud Case

docs.abstract: KPMG agrees to pay $9 million to settle government accusations that it helped group of hospitals in Florida and Kentucky defraud Medicare through use of bogus expense claims; government lawsuit against KPMG is outgrowth of multiyear probe of company now known as HCA-The Healthcare Co; Federal investigators have said in court records that they think HCA and its predecessor companies engaged in corporatewide effort to cheat government by misrepresenting certain expenses, which were then reimbursed by Medicare; at issue is complex, little-understood program known as federal cost-reporting system, under which government has paid billions of dollars to hospitals and other health care providers, including hundreds of millions of dollars in payments each year to HCA (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Vicky Pagán-Leedy was apartment-hunting in Paris with her husband, Robert, when the real estate agent told them two jetliners had crashed into the World Trade Center. The couple, who were planning to move to Paris a few weeks later, suddenly felt overwhelmed by a desire to return to their home in Evansville, Ind. ''We wanted to be with family and friends,'' Ms. Pagán-Leedy said. They did return to Evansville -- to pack. Still, she said, she harbored doubts right up to the last minute. ''It's not really a fear that something is going to happen to me,'' she said. ''It's just, when things are like this, it's not the right time to make these major changes.''
docs.abstract: Americans who work overseas or who are contemplating work overseas now weigh its attractions against safety concerned arising from terrorist attack of Sept 11; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: On the War Front AGAINST THE TALIBAN -- United States warplanes struck Taliban soldiers on the front lines for a third day. Pentagon officials said for the first time that their goal was to choke off the group's supplies. A1 THE COMMAND STRUCTURE -- President Bush's war team is blending an approach used to run the gulf war with a more civilian-managed model used later in Kosovo. B1

docs.lead_paragraph: United States insurance executives raised concerns today about the ability of Lloyd's of London to pay its share of claims in the attack on the World Trade Center. At a meeting with regulators here, the American insurers were reacting to a decision last week by regulators to permit Lloyd's to reduce by 40 percent the amount of money it sets aside as a fund to guarantee payment of its claims.

headline.main: U.S. Insurers Are Concerned About Lloyd's

docs.abstract: United States insurance executives, at conference called by National Association of Insurance Commissioners, cite concern about Lloyd's of London's ability to pay its share of World Trade Center attack claims; react to decision to let Lloyd's cut from 100 percent to 60 percent funds it sets aside to guarantee claims payment; Lloyd's and its regulators say Lloyd's can meet obligations; Lloyd's puts its World Trade Center claims at $8 billion, all but $1.9 billion to be reimbursed by other insurers; analysts note much of reimbursement is to come from companies within Lloyd's, including some that were financially weak before attacks (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Hammering the Taliban MORE STRIKES -- American warplanes carried out their first substantial attack on the Taliban's front-line troops north of Kabul as Secretary of State Colin L. Powell indicated that the United States would like the opposition Northern Alliance to advance toward Kabul, the Afghan capital. The raids and Secretary Powell's virtual invitation to the Northern Alliance to surround Kabul suggest a growing urgency in Washington about the military operation. A1
